Package myMath

Class Polynom

  • java.lang.Object
    • myMath.Polynom
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    cont_function, function, Polynom_able
    public class Polynom
extends java.lang.Object
implements Polynom_able
    This class represents a Polynom with add, multiply functionality, it also should support the following: 1. Riemann's Integral: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riemann_integral 2. Finding a numerical value between two values (currently support root only f(x)=0). 3. Derivative
    Author:
    OrShemesh && YaaraGoldenberg

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor Description
      Polynom()
      This is default constructor
      Polynom​(java.lang.String str)
      This constructor gets string and cut by "+", and turns it into Polynom Example : 2x^2+2^x+-5
      Polynom​(Polynom other)
      This is copy constructor

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method Description
      void add​(Monom m1)
      Add Monom to this Polynom Example : f(x)=x^2+2x g(x)=3x^2---> f(x)+g(x)=4x^2+2x
      void add​(Polynom_able p1)
      Add Polynom to this Polynom Example : f(x)=x^2+2x g(x)=8x^3-3x^2+4x---> f(x)+g(x)=8x^3-2x^2+6x
      double area​(double x0, double x1, double eps)
      Compute Riemann's Integral over this Polynom starting from x0, till x1 using eps size steps, see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riemann_integral
      double areaNegative​(double x0, double x1, double eps)
      because in the first area function we can't find a negative area, we create a new area function that calculate the negative area in the function.
      Polynom_able copy()
      This constructor gets Polynom from the copy constructor , and do deep copy.
      Polynom_able derivative()
      Compute a new Polynom which is the derivative of this Polynom
      boolean equals​(Polynom_able p1)
      This function get Polynom and checking if there equals example : f(x1)=2x^3+2x == f(x2)=2x^3+2x return true
      double f​(double x)
      This function represents a simple function of type y=f(x), where both y and x are real numbers.
      boolean isZero()
      This function checking if the Polynom is 0
      java.util.Iterator<Monom> iteretor()
      This statement on Iterator
      void multiply​(Polynom_able p1)
      Multiply Polynom by this Polynom Example : f(x)=x^2+2x g(x)=3x^2+2 ---> f(x)*g(x)=3.0*x^4+6.0*x^3+2.0*x^2+4.0*x^1
      double root​(double x0, double x1, double eps)
      * Compute a Riman's integral from x0 to x1 in eps steps.
      void substract​(Polynom_able p1)
      Sub Polynom to this Polynom Example : f(x)=x^2+2x g(x)=8x^3-3x^2+4x---> f(x)-g(x)=8x^3+4x^2+6x
      java.lang.String toString()
      This function print the Polynom

      • root

        public double root​(double x0,
                   double x1,
                   double eps)
        * Compute a Riman's integral from x0 to x1 in eps steps.
        Specified by:
        root in interface Polynom_able
        Parameters:
        x0 - starting point
        x1 - end point
        eps - positive step value
        Returns:
        the approximated area above X-axis below this function bounded in the range of [x0,x1] see : https://he.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D7%A9%D7%99%D7%98%D7%AA_%D7%94%D7%97%D7%A6%D7%99%D7%99%D7%94

      • area

        public double area​(double x0,
                   double x1,
                   double eps)
        Compute Riemann's Integral over this Polynom starting from x0, till x1 using eps size steps, see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riemann_integral
        Specified by:
        area in interface cont_function
        Specified by:
        area in interface Polynom_able
        Parameters:
        x0 - starting pooint
        x1 - end point
        eps - positive step value
        Returns:
        the approximated area above the x-axis below this Polynom and between the [x0,x1] range.

      • areaNegative

        public double areaNegative​(double x0,
                           double x1,
                           double eps)
        because in the first area function we can't find a negative area, we create a new area function that calculate the negative area in the function.
